questions.question:
Let \(G_1, G_2 \) be Context-Free Grammars (CFGs) and \(R \) be a regular expression. For a grammar \(G \), let \(L(G) \) denote the language generated by \(G \).
Which ONE among the following questions is decidable?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-2)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the following two languages over the alphabet \(\{a, b, c\}\), where \(m\) and \(n\) are natural numbers:

\(L_1 = \{ a^m b^m c^{m+n} \mid m, n \geq 1 \}\)
\(L_2 = \{ a^m b^n c^{m+n} \mid m, n \geq 1 \}\)

Which ONE of the following statements is CORRECT?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
options:
B.

\(L_1\) is a context-free language but \(L_2\) is not a context-free language.

C.

\(L_1\) is not a context-free language but \(L_2\) is a context-free language.
questions.correct_answer:
C.

\(L_1\) is not a context-free language but \(L_2\) is a context-free language.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the following context-free grammar \(G\), where \(S\), \(A\), and \(B\) are the variables (non-terminals), \(a\) and \(b\) are the terminal symbols, \(S\) is the start variable, and the rules of \(G\) are described as:

\(S \to aaB \mid Abb\)
\(A \to a \mid aA\)
\(B \to b \mid bB\)

Which ONE of the languages \(L(G)\) is accepted by \(G\)?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
options:
B.

\(L(G) = \{ a^n b^{2n} \mid n \geq 1 \} \cup \{ a^{2n} b^n \mid n \geq 1 \}\)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is/are CORRECT?

(GATE CSE 2023)
options:
A.

The intersection of two regular languages is regular.

B.

The intersection of two context-free languages is context-free.

C.

The intersection of two recursive languages is recursive.

D.

The intersection of two recursively enumerable languages is recursively enumerable.
correct_answer:
A.

The intersection of two regular languages is regular.

C.

The intersection of two recursive languages is recursive.

D.

The intersection of two recursively enumerable languages is recursively enumerable.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the following languages:

\( \begin{aligned} L_1&= \{ ww|w \in \{a,b \}^* \} \\ L_2&= \{a^nb^nc^m | m,n \geq 0 \} \\ L_3 &= \{a^mb^nc^n|m,n \geq 0 \} \end{aligned}\)

Which of the following statements is/are FALSE?

(GATE CSE 2022)
options:
A.

\(L_1\) is not context-free but \(L_2\) and \(L_3\) are deterministic context-free.

questions.question:
Consider the following languages:

\( \begin{aligned} L_1&= \{a^n wa^n|w \in \{a,b \}^* \} \\ L_2&= \{wxw^R | w,x \in \{a,b \}^*, |w|,|x| \gt 0 \} \end{aligned}\)

Note that \(w^R\) is the reversal of the string \(w\). Which of the following is/are TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2022)
options:
D.

\(L_1\) and \(L_2\) are context-free but not regular.

III. \( \{a^{m}b^{n}c^{p}d^{q}|m=n=p \; and \; p\neq q, \; where \; m,n,p,q\geq 0 \} \)
IV. \(\{a^{m}b^{n}c^{p}d^{q}|mn=p+q, \; where\; m,n,p,q\geq 0\}\)

All the three languages are context free

questions.question:
The two grammars given below generate a language over the alphabet \(\{x, y, z\}\)
G1 : \(S \rightarrow x \mid z \mid x \ S \mid z \ S \mid y \ B\)
\(B \rightarrow y \mid z \mid y \ B \mid z \ B\)
G2 : \(S \rightarrow y \mid z \mid y \ S \mid z \ S \mid x \ B\)
\(B \rightarrow y \mid y \ S\)
Which one of the following choices describes the properties satisfied by the strings in these languages?

(GATE IT 2007)
options:
A.

G1 : No y appears before any x
G2 : Every x is followed by at least one y

B.

G1 : No y appears before any x
G2 : No x appears before any y

C.

G1 : No y appears after any x
G2 : Every x is followed by at least one y

D.

G1 : No y appears after any x
G2 : Every y is followed by at least one x
questions.correct_answer:
A.

G1 : No y appears before any x
G2 : Every x is followed by at least one y

questions.question:
Define a context free languages \(L \in \{0, 1\}^*, \text{init} (L) = \{u \mid uv \in L\) for some v in \(\{0, 1\}^*\}\) ( in other words, \(\text{init}(L)\) is the set of prefixes of L)
Let \(L = \{w \mid w \text{ is nonempty and has an equal number of $0$'s and $1$'s}\}\) Then \(\text{init}(L)\) is:

(GATE CSE 1996)
options:
A.

the set of all binary strings with unequal number of 0's and 1's

B.

the set of all binary strings including null string

C.

the set of all binary strings with exactly one more 0 than the number of 1's or one more 1 than the number of 0's
questions.correct_answer:
B.

the set of all binary strings including null string
